awd_titl_txt: I-Corps:  Customer discovery to explore Wildflower Turf's rapid meadow technology for the US market
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to enable more effective commercialization of a sustainable lawn alternative in the form of wildflower sod. Grass lawns are ubiquitous in the continental US covering an estimated 40 million acres of land, an area more than three times that of any other crop, including corn, soy and wheat. While grass lawns are beloved by American landowners, they are expensive, requiring more water, pesticide and fertilizer inputs than any other crop. These inputs degrade waterways and create biological deserts. In response, there is a growing call for sustainable lawn alternatives with an emphasis on native wildflower meadows. Despite the demand for meadowscapes, grass only turf continues to dominate the US landscape, in part, because the United States (US) does not have dependable, effective tools for meadow establishment. Introduction of wildflower sod/turf products to the US market will contribute to desired societal outcomes; such as meeting objectives mandated by state and federal water quality policies and initiatives, increasing biodiversity and helping ensure the health of pollinating insect communities, which provide food security through the pollination of wild and cultivated crops. 

This I-Corps project will advance the teams knowledge of potential barriers to widespread adoption of wildflower meadows. While the ecological benefits of wildflower meadows are fairly well understood, few studies have investigated meadow implementation from the perspective of land managers, landscape professionals and communities. Understanding the market obstacles of replacing high input lawns with sustainable flowering meadows is the first step in finding viable solutions. The technology being pursued is a biodiverse meadow sod comprised of native grasses and wildflowers. Conceptually, it is similar to traditional sod in that the turf is moveable and easy to install. The US team has partnered with a UK company which developed the production system on which the new technology is based, and has been the leading supplier of wildflower turf in Great Britain since 2003. The new IP will include adapting the UK growing system to 1) work with US plant species and climates, and 2) development of native seed mixes that grow well in the production system and that will provide the desired aesthetics for an urban setting

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Project Outcome Report for Wildflower Turf, US

INTRO

There is a growing call for sustainable lawn alternatives with an emphasis on native wildflower meadows. Despite the demand for meadowscapes, lawns continue to dominate the US landscape; partly because we lack dependable and effective tools for meadow establishment. The UK has developed a novel solution, a scalable technology that produces species-rich wildflower sod that is quick and easy to install. Introducing wildflower/meadow sod adapted for the US market would support multiple societal objectives; including, improving soil and water quality to comply with state and federal regulations, increasing biodiversity, and mitigating bee declines to protect pollination services for crops. The University of Maryland?s Bee Lab partnered with Wildflower Turf LLC, the leading supplier of wildflower turf in the UK, to explore the commercial viability of US region appropriate wildflower sod. Our first priority was to gain an in-depth understanding of our target market, their biggest challenges, and whether wildflower sod is a viable solution. It was soon apparent that while knowledgeable about bees and wildflowers, the scientists on our US team knew little about how to turn these ideas into real market solutions. The NSF I-Corps? program paved the way for a successful venture by guiding us through the customer discovery process and multiple iterations of our business model canvas.

WHAT WE DID

Winter 2019, team Wildflower Turf, US participated in the NSF I-Corps? intensive 7-week customer discovery program. Major activities included:

  • Joining the in-person entrepreneurial immersion kickoff session, which included conducting and evaluating our initial face-to-face interviews with potential customers, and doing a deep dive into our main target market and value proposition
  • Participating in a weekly online curriculum that included instructor and team presentations and active exchanges between the instructor, our team and other teams in the cohort
  • Conducting a total of 114 customer interviews (108 in-person and 6 via telephone) with potential customers and potential partners from our proposed target markets
    • The discovery process took us to seven different states (CA, DC, DE, MD, NC, NJ and PA) and the UK to interview their early adopters, which provided insights into what motivated them to try the products, their specific applications, and what they valued most about wildflower sod
    • Attending three different trade shows/conferences (Turf Grass International Conference in NC, the New Jersey Landscape Contractors Association, and the Eastern Native Grass Symposium in PA) so we could learn from and interview industry experts
    • Sharing our customer discovery findings at the closing session with our cohort to facilitate group learning

After completing the customer discovery program, we used remaining grant funds to grow Wildflower Turf prototypes. The prototypes were used to create a demo garden, giving us the opportunity to monitor establishment success. The top photo shows turf loaded and ready for transport. The bottom photo is a collage of the demo garden and how the space was ?instantly? transformed from a lawn to a biodiverse pocket meadow.

LESSONS LEARNED AND BROADER IMPACTS

Results from our interviews suggest that our target customers are landscape professionals (architects, designers and contractors), who specialize in green infrastructure projects. Wildflower Turf?s main value proposition is that it provides rapid groundcover whilst suppressing weeds, enabling a wide range of applications in the built environment; such as green roofs, naturalized borders and sloped areas. Wildflower Turf?s ecological benefits also ranked high, particularly nutrient reduction, erosion control and providing habitat for pollinators and other wildlife. Extensive customer discovery through the NSF I-Corps also advanced our knowledge of potential barriers to widespread adoption of wildflower sod, as well as traditional seeding methods. The two major hurdles to market entry are public acceptance of naturalistic landscape design, a departure from less formal, tidy lawns, and a lack of contractors with meadow maintenance expertise. The lessons learned have informed both our business model and commercial planning.

OUTCOMES OF PROJECT

Since completing the NSF I-Corps program, an official partnership has been formed between US team members and Wildflower Turf, LLC in the UK, including a formal agreement with an experienced CEO. Company formation, fund-raising and locating suitable farmland for growing Wildflower Turf are in progress as of July 2020. Our current projections are that Wildflower Turf will be commercially available in the northeast by spring 2022. Wildflower Turf products using northeast native meadows species will support regional conservation landscaping initiatives (i.e., Gaitersburg Conservation Landscaping Program, Rockville Conservation Landscaping, and Northern Virginia?s Conservation Assistance Project) and provide the landscaping industry with a novel tool for creating aesthetically pleasing and sustainable spaces in the built environment. We anticipate expanding to other eco-regions of the US within 5 ? 10 years. We would like to thank the NSF I-Corps 2019 winter cohort instructors for challenging us and broadening our thinking, and the NSF for funding this research.

 


Last Modified: 12/19/2022
Modified by: Dennis Vanengelsdorp

Image
  • Before and after images of prototype wildflower turf meadow
    Lisa Kuder
    Royalty-free (unrestricted use)
    Dennis Vanengelsdorp
    Wildflower Turf demo garden
